ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ROAD PRICING SCHEME AT CENTRAL EXPRESSWAY


    1. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for Communications whether the latest road pricing scheme introduced at the Central Expressway has worsened the jams at other roads.

     The Minister of State for Communications (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the objective of Road Pricing Scheme (RPS) on our expressways is to keep our main transport arteries free-flowing. These expressways are also our economic arteries. They are designed to move people and goods quickly and efficiently, and save them time and money. The recent modification of RPS on CTE has achieved this objective. Average speed on the CTE has improved from 25 kph to above 60 kph. Volume of traffic using the CTE during peak hours has dropped by 20%.

Column: 528



    The changes have resulted in some traffic moving to alternative routes around the CTE. Traffic surveys show that traffic volume on these roads has increased by about 3% during the RPS operation hours. While there are localised congestion at some stretches, the average speed of vehicles on these roads is about 20 kph. This is comparable to travel speeds prior to the amendment of RPS on CTE on 1st July. LTA expects traffic conditions along these routes to stabilise in due course as motorists adjust their travel patterns.

    Motorists who do not wish to pay for a licence to use the CTE and who do not wish to add to the congestion along the alternative routes should seriously consider several other options. They can adjust their travel pattern by staggering their travel times, or they can shift to public transport or they can car-pool with a friend.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Ministry consider taking certain measures to alleviate the jams along the alternative routes?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, where possible, LTA will adjust traffic lights and carry out localised road improvements along the affected roads to remove any bottlenecks and facilitate smoother traffic flows. However, motorists must realise that the objective of the RPS is to ease the congestion along our expressways and to provide them with a choice of fast transit. So motorists must also consider these other options that I have mentioned, such as taking public transport, park-and-ride, car pooling or changing their time of travel.

    I am pleased to inform Members that the public response to the four new express bus services introduced in conjunction with the extended RPS scheme since 5th May 1997 has been encouraging. Due to commuters' requests, I am informed that SBS would be revising the schedules of its express buses to improve their frequency and capacity provision.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Would the bus companies be encouraged to provide more such express services?

Column: 529



     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, currently, there are four express bus services - one from the North, two from the North-east, and one from the East - and these are designed to address the congestion problem that the Member has mentioned. SBS will review from time to time not just its frequency and capacity but also other bus service possibilities.

     Encik Ibrahim bin Othman (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, could the Minister of State consider taking away one gantry point near Toa Payoh at the Central Expressway (CTE) so as not to make things difficult for residents who want to use the PIE to go to Changi Airport in the morning?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, the two gantry points are complementary. In our analysis, we discovered that there are motorists who make use of that stretch of the expressway between the two gantry points to go to the PIE. But that contributed to congestion and caused kickbacks as far back as the first gantry point and further up north. On the whole, we prefer to have the two gantry points so as to provide an effective solution.

     Encik Ibrahim bin Othman: Sir, could the Minister of State then consider allowing traffic that goes towards Changi Airport in the morning to use the CTE and PIE without payment because it does not cause congestion in the morning?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, as I explained, they use that stretch of the expressway and therefore they are contributing congestion. The only way to reduce congestion is to ensure that those who use that stretch of the expressway also have to pay. If they value faster transit they should use the CTE.

APPLICATION SYSTEM FOR HAWKER STALLS


    2. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry has any plan to change the application system for hawker stalls.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, vacant hawker stalls are rented out to the public through

Column: 530

a tender system. The Ministry has no plans to change the current method of allocating stalls to the public.

     Encik Harun bin A. Ghani (Hong Kah): Sir, could the Minister reconsider his decision so that the lower income or hardship cases have a chance to tender for a hawker stall? Otherwise, they would not have a chance to obtain a hawker stall because the present tender prices are very high.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the tender process is open to everybody. There are two sectors of stalls available - one is the market produce stalls and the other is the cooked food stalls. We have about 70 market produce stalls and 25 cooked food stalls being tendered out every two months. So far, for the market produce stalls, the take-up rate has been about 70%. I would suggest that the hardship cases, if they are really interested in having a stall, should try to participate in the tender programme for the market produce stalls where the likelihood of their being successful would be pretty good.

STAGED ACCIDENTS
(Complaints)


    3. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the Police Force has received complaints of "staged accidents".

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, Police takes a serious view of staged accidents. It is monitoring the situation very closely. These accidents are related to the problem of workshop crew touting for business.

    Traffic Police's assessment is that instances of staged accidents are relatively few. From time to time, Police receives reports from motorists claiming that the circumstances under which accidents they were involved in were suspicious. Police investigations into these reports have not disclosed any evidence of staging, although in some of them, there was sufficient evidence to proceed on careless driving.

Column: 531



    Three cases of suspected staging were cited by the Straits Times on 7th July 1997. Traffic Police has carefully investigated them. There is insufficient evidence to prove that any of the accidents was staged.

    Police will continue to investigate cases where staging of accidents is suspected or where workshop crew persistently annoy, harass, or intimidate motorists in an effort to offer their services. Since 1995, there have been three reported cases of touting. The culprits in two of the cases have been convicted whilst the third case is still under investigation.

    This is not the first time that the issue of staged traffic accidents and touting has surfaced. In 1991, Police received numerous complaints of highway touts pestering accident victims for repair services. The touts had arrived almost immediately after an accident occurred on the road.

    Police then conducted an operation against highway touts and arrested 13 persons. Police also seized two transceivers which were used to listen to emergency service frequencies. As a result, the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore (TAS) Act was amended in 1993 to deter such unauthorised access.

    These activities abated considerably. But in 1994 reports of such practices resurfaced. Police responded with strict enforcement against touts and towing crew plying the thoroughfares. Police also collated information on suspected workshops involved in hiring accident stagers and monitored them closely. Further, Police secured its radio transmission network by encrypting its channels to prevent eavesdropping by touts. The enforcement action successfully cleared up touting activities until the recent cases were reported in the press.

    Police recognises that enforcement action alone cannot be the solution. Other than difficulty in securing evidence, sporadic reports of possible occurrences require intensive manpower resources to investigate effectively.

Column: 532



    Police has met with Mr Tan Kin Lian, CEO of NTUC INCOME to discuss the problem. His assessment is that staging of accidents is one facet of a wider set of problems which include touting and fraudulent insurance claims. The problem has to be addressed at source with the motor insurance industry taking the initiative.

    The motor insurance industry can do this by looking into the existing practice of assessment and claims which may be circumvented by workshops involved with touts and accident stagers.

    The motoring public can also play their part by being vigilant when driving. They should keep a safe distance from the vehicles in front, even when vehicles try to cut into their paths. Also, they should not be pressurised into accepting the services of towing crews at the scene of accident and should report any touting activities to the Police.

    While the problem of staged accidents is not widespread, the public can be assured that Police will take strict enforcement action and adopt a serious view of all such reports. All allegations of staged accidents will be investigated thoroughly. Whenever there is sufficient evidence, offenders will be prosecuted in court where deterrent sentences will be pressed against them.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Sir, I think Members of this House have from time to time also received similar complaints from residents as well and we can all agree to take a serious view of this matter as it endangers lives on the roads. My question to the Minister of State is whether the current legislation is sufficient to tackle this problem and whether the penalties are sufficient deterrents.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, if a person is caught for touting, as had happened, he is punished under the Miscellaneous Offences (Public Order and Nuisance) Act for which a person, if liable and convicted, can be fined not less than $1,000 and not more than $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six

Column: 533

months or to both. If it is a second or subsequent conviction, he may be liable to a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year or to both. Of course, if a person is convicted of staging an accident, then it depends on what consequences have arisen. If, as a result of the accident, people are hurt, then a range of penalties is open under which he may be liable, including for serious cases, even under section 304 of the Penal Code (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) or voluntarily causing grievous hurt or hurt or mischief. It depends on what arises from the accident. I think the penalties are in place. The question, of course, is how to ensure that there is sufficient evidence.

    In any case, I would like to assure Mr Chng and the House that we would take a comprehensive approach. Police is at the end, ie, when a report comes in, we investigate. But I have asked Traffic Police to work with the motor insurance industry - I think that is the nub of the problem and the way to a solution - so that they can come together and agree on a practice, for example, of authorised workshops. To do this, I think, the industry must come together, because if some break ranks, then it does not work. So we will see what arises from these discussions.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, saying that touting and staging of accidents are part and parcel of the same problem, will the Minister of State agree that $1,000 fine seems rather low under today's conditions and, at the same time, in view of the fact that we have so far failed to bring many of these people to book?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: As I say, these possible offences are linked - touting, submitting of fraudulent claims and, possibly, staging of accidents. But, of course, touting encompasses a host of activities, not just touting on the roads. Touting can also take place in a retail setting. But I think Mr Chng's point is that if a person is caught for touting with regard to possible staged accidents, then higher penalties should be imposed. I can ask Police to consider this point.

Column: 534

PASIR RIS MRT STATION
(Construction of covered linkways)


    4. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for Communications whether covered walkways from the Pasir Ris MRT Station to nearby bus stops and a vehicle drop-off and pick-up point will be constructed and, if so, when construction is expected to commence.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (for the Minister for Communications): I am pleased to inform the Member that the Land Transport Authority (LTA) will construct covered linkways from the Pasir Ris MRT station to nearby bus stops along Pasir Ris Drive 1. The linkways will incorporate a vehicle drop-off and pick-up point along Pasir Ris Central. The design for the linkways is being developed and the LTA plans to call for tenders later this year. Construction work will take about eight months to complete, after the tender is awarded.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar): Sir, I wonder whether the Minister of State can tell the House whether such a project will be implemented island-wide, where applicable.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Members can put in their requests to the LTA and LTA will assess the merits of the requests on a case-by-case basis. LTA will then reply to the Member.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang: As a matter of convenience, would the Ministry be able to get the officials to study such a project on an island-wide basis, rather than on an ad hoc basis?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Firstly, Sir, I have told LTA that, wherever possible, LTA would contact the Member, who requested for such facilities, to study the request together with the engineers from LTA. So LTA will be helpful in considering each request. As you can see from the request, it involves drop-off and pick-up points. So it may not be applicable in every case. It is difficult to do a comprehensive study for all constituencies. But I would encourage Members to take up their requests with LTA, and LTA would try to be helpful.

Column: 535



     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister of State will recall that this is one of the issues raised in the paper "World Class Land Transport System", whereby it was envisaged that all MRT stations be integrated with the bus interchanges, to make it convenient for all residents. So why is the Ministry or LTA not looking into this issue, as raised by my hon. friend, on an island-wide basis and not on an ad hoc basis?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, I am talking of the more unique requests. But for bus stops and linkways, I am pleased to inform Members that LTA has decided to implement a nation-wide programme to upgrade the bus shelters and the linkways to MRT stations. That programme would cost about $24 million.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, while supporting the issue raised by Mr Chng Hee Kok, what I want to ask is why is LTA not proactive in trying to look at some of the problems.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, as I said, as far as proactiveness is concerned, that is what they are going to do. They are now going to implement this nation-wide programme of upgrading the bus stops and to fit the programme into the IUP and MUP of the constituencies, so that when you have a new environment after the IUP, you also have new linkways and bus shelters. So these are the programmes that the LTA has taken the initiative to launch. But as for other requests, as I mentioned, pick-up points and drop-off points, I do not think they will be applicable in every case.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, besides IUP and MUP, there are other commuter needs. Why is the LTA not looking at other types of needs other than this tying-up with IUP and MUP?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: I am not saying that we will only tie up with IUP and MUP. There are criteria for upgrading of bus shelters, for instance. You cannot upgrade a bus shelter if it is only a few years old. There are certain criteria. Where there are IUP and MUP, I think you will get priority because we do not want to have a case where you have got a brand new

Column: 536

environment but a very old bus shelter. So that is not so good. This is the rationale behind our programme.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: A more general question, Sir. I share the concerns of my colleagues. Is the LTA doing anything about the paper on the "World Class Land Transport System"? It is not collecting dust, I hope.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, this question is not relevant to the question that the Member has asked about bus shelters and linkways. I think we will answer that question in the Committee of Supply on the progress that we have made for a World Class Land Transport System.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Just to add to what my Minister of State said just now. I would like to assure Mr Chng and the rest of the Members of this House that the White Paper on a World Class Land Transport System is not collecting dust. In fact, as the Minister of State has said, he will be giving further details during the debate in the Committee of Supply. But on the specific point raised by Mr Chng and Dr Vasoo and the rest, there is in fact an on-going programme to connect all MRT stations with the nearest bus stops and other commuter facilities of that nature are now in the works. I think the specific question that was raised on whether there was going to be extension to the MRT station in Mr Charles Chong's constituency has been answered.

Column: 536

TENDER FOR FOOD COURT AT SERANGOON CENTRAL WET MARKET


    5. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for National Development why the Housing and Development Board has not been able to attract successful tender for the space for a food court at the Serangoon Central Wet Market after one year.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, besides the Serangoon Central Wet Market, the three storey building also included four retail units, one of which is designated as a food court.

Column: 537



    HDB has so far let out three of the four retail units for use as a fast food restaurant, a departmental store and a family amusement centre. For the remaining food court unit, HDB has completed many rounds of tender exercises but has found very few demand for the unit. No tenant has been found so far. This shows that the eight other eating establishments currently operating in Serangoon Town Centre and the private sector eating outlets in Serangoon are sufficient to meet the needs of the residents. The latest tender exercise for this unit is currently in progress and will close at the end of the month. If this latest tender exercise is unsuccessful, the HDB will let out the unit for other uses.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Does the Minister agree that this space was not able to be tendered out because the minimum reserve price is too high?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, as is the present practice, all tenders put out have a minimum reserve price. For the six tender exercises which were completed, there were either no tender bids at all or one or two tender bids which came below HDB's reserve tender price. For example, the latest tender, the sixth tender, managed to attract only one bid. This is obviously not a competitive tender and therefore it was not awarded.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether HDB should consider lowering the reserve tender price in order to have a successful tender, rather than leave the space there vacant for so long?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I replied earlier, the space will not be left vacant. If this latest tender does not show a good result, we will let it out for other uses.

     Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I ask how does the HDB arrive at this reserve price?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The current Government practice on tender goes something like this. On the date and time of the closing of the tender, the Chief

Column: 538

Valuer or the Valuation Officer of HDB will submit a bid considering the market evidence of what would be the going market price. So the Government agency evaluating the tender and the person making the evaluation are two separate bodies. In a Government tender, whoever is the agency, HDB or URA, will close the tender on a particular date and time. At that date and time, the Chief Valuer participates in the tender just like any other private sector agency. The Chief Valuer will put in a tender bid stating what he determines to be the reserve price, evaluating the market evidence. Similarly for HDB tenders, the same practice is done. The Commercial Property Section runs the tender, but the Valuation Officer in HDB is a separate agency that will put in a reserve bid.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask whether only market forces are taken into consideration or whether the needs of the community around there are considered?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As the evidence shows, there are enough eating outlets in the Serangoon Road area. Serangoon Road is not an isolated HDB town. It is built close to existing food outlets. There are also food outlets within the Town Centre. So obviously there are enough food outlets and the needs of the residents are met.

PASIR RIS NEIGHBOURHOOD 7 SHOPPING CENTRE
(Reasons for delay in operation)


    6. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for National Development when will the Pasir Ris Neighbourhood 7 shopping centre be operational and what are the reasons for the delay.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, Neighbourhood Centre 7, consisting of 40 shops, one supermarket and four eating establishments, was completed and taken over for management by the HDB in February this year.

    HDB had invited tenders for the commercial premises in this Neighbourhood Centre in April this year. The successful tenderers have signed the

Column: 539

tenancy agreement, and the majority of them are now renovating their premises. As the renovation works would take approximately two months for most shops, this Neighbourhood Centre will be operational by late August.

BUKIT GOMBAK CONSTITUENCY
(Provision of permanent parking place for heavy vehicles)


    7. Mr Ang Mong Seng asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry has any plans to provide more heavy vehicle parking places island-wide and when such a permanent parking place will be built in Bukit Gombak Constituency.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the URA is constructing another 10 heavy vehicle parks throughout the island. The first of these vehicle parks will be completed by early next year while the rest will be completed progressively by the end of 1998. These heavy vehicle parks will provide a total of about 2,500 lots.

    A heavy vehicle park will be constructed in the Bukit Gombak Constituency at Bukit Batok East Avenue 2. This heavy vehicle park, which will be completed in July 1998, will have 220 lots.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [11th July, 1997],

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1997 to 31st March, 1998." - [Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

Column: 540


1.00 pm

     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, this year's budget has been announced at a rather unusual time in July, instead of March every year. It has also come at a time when the US economy is surging ahead very strongly with low inflation, with the Dow Jones hitting a record 8000 recently while the regional economies here seem to be taking a beating with the Thai baht and the Philippine peso having depreciated significantly against the US dollar. The ringgit has also come under pressure lately. Even the Singapore dollar has weakened somewhat against the US dollar.

    There is general consensus that we are facing an economic slowdown today. The good news so far is that it does not seem to be as bad as the one we experienced back in 1985-87, many of whom have already forgotten as it was so brief. In fact, this slowdown is useful as it serves to remind all of us that prices do not just go up one way. They can also come down and stay down, just like the share prices have done since January 1994. On the other hand, the bad news is that our costs of doing business have been creeping up, eroding our competitiveness. And unless some concerted action led by the Government is taken, the slowdown may become much more severe.

    In the light of this economic backdrop, it is not surprising that the business community expects the budget to address the issue of competitiveness and to offer some relief to the high costs of doing business in Singapore.

    The Government Parliamentary Committee for Finance, Trade and Industry met up for informal dialogue sessions with three trade associations, just before the Budget Statement was announced, namely, the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, the Singapore Confederation of Industries and the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry. They had wishlists which were largely not met by the budget. I will dwell upon them later. Our GPC also met up with our resource

Column: 541

panel members comprising many prominent business people and professionals from a wide spectrum of the finance and business community. And this we did after the Budget Statement was announced. Their reaction generally was that the budget benefitted only the larger financial institutions and a small select group of business people involved in logistics. The local business community was generally disappointed.

    I share some of the sentiments of the local business community. However, if we regard this more like an interim budget and also remember that the Committee set up to look into the long term competitiveness of Singapore is still hard at work, we put these into perspective, we will feel less disappointed. I think we should also be grateful that there were no new tax increases, not even the perennial ones on cigarettes and liquor. We should also not forget the number of positive tax reliefs on the personal side.

    In my view, this year's budget is moderately positive, although skewed too much towards the foreign financial community.

    This budget does not address the main concern of business people, and that is, reducing the cost of doing business in Singapore so that our enterprises can become more competitive vis-a-vis our neighbours. I believe some time before the Budget Statement, the JTC did announce the freezing of rentals for industrial properties at current prices. There were also some adjustments made to the foreign workers' levy for certain sectors. There is a perception that nobody seems to be monitoring and coordinating measures to contain, if not to reduce the cost of doing business here. Column: 542

message I would like to put across today is that our business community is extremely anxious about the current state of affairs and would like to see an integrated Government approach in dealing with the issue of cost.

    The Government should also not hesitate to revisit fundamental assumptions, or "sacred cows" that many policies are predicated upon. Today, many policies have been formulated based upon a mix of Government controls and free market forces. Perhaps, we should challenge some of these premises today and ask ourselves whether our economy and the people are mature enough to let market forces have free and full play. I will touch on these in greater detail in the Committee of Supply.

    Let me now deal with the budget details, item by item.

Corporate Tax Rate

    The corporate tax rate is held at 26% although the announced long term rate is 25%. I agree that at 26% today, we are already one of the lowest in the world, after Hong Kong, for corporate tax rate. Since we have brought this down to 26% only last year, I agree that there is no real urgency to bring it down further.

    For the longer term, however, I would like to ask the Minister for Finance to consider a multi-tier corporate tax rate that will help small local growing companies that need to plough back their profits into the business. For example, the first $2 million in taxable income could be taxed at, say, 15%, the next $3 million could be taxed at 20% and the rest above $5 million at the long term rate of 25%. In this case, local companies could be defined as companies with 100% Singaporean ownership. This concession could be given for an initial period of between five to 10 years.

    We are already helping many MNCs in Singapore in a similar way by granting them pioneer tax status for 10 years in the first instance. And this period, I am told, is sometimes extended depending on further investments made in their plants in Singapore.

Column: 543



    In the financial sector, we have already introduced similar multi-tier corporate tax rates, although in their case, the tax rate is lower or even exempt for selected activities above a certain threshold.

Tax Incentives for Financial Services Sector

    Most of us do not begrudge the tax incentives given to the financial services sector to further attract high value-added activities, mega fund managers or reputable credit rating agencies to Singapore. In this way, we enhance the development of Singapore as an international financial centre. The question most frequently asked, however, is how do these tax incentives translate into benefits for Singaporeans. These tax incentives are mainly benefitted by the foreign financial firms. Although there are some requirements for some of these firms to employ a certain number of staff based in Singapore in order to qualify for these tax incentives, many firms simply transfer their expatriate staff from their home country to Singapore. Many of them bemoan the difficulty in recruiting qualified local staff but, at the same time, they are reluctant to train younger local staff for fear of job hopping among them once they are trained. So they simply poach from one another and drive up the wage costs in the process. There is therefore little transfer of technical expertise to our local people.

    In Thailand, I am told, foreign financial institutions are restricted in the number of expatriates allowed to be brought in. I am not suggesting that we do likewise here, but I certainly feel that more training of younger staff should be undertaken so that our pool of qualified financial professionals can be increased in the long run. If all the firms involved are compelled to train younger local staff, there will be less fear of poaching among them. This is important if we want to add breadth and depth to our financial markets. So I hope the Minister for Finance will look into the possibility of linking some of these tax incentives to the imposition of some requirement to train younger local staff to add to our pool of financial expertise. In

Column: 544

the longer term, this will also ease the tight labour market for financial professionals and make it easier to further attract more financial institutions to Singapore.

Overseas Enterprise Incentive (OEI)

    The OEI was introduced as part of the Government's effort to encourage Singaporean companies to regionalise. Thus far, the tax incentives are aimed at companies that are profitable, with income or dividends to remit home. The further relaxation of the OEI scheme is welcomed.

    Companies that venture overseas usually do not make profits in the initial years. Right now, their losses cannot be grouped together, although they can be carried over for a number of years at the individual company level. To further encourage regionalisation by local companies, the Minister may wish to consider allowing such companies to group their losses for an initial period of, say, five years, provided certain conditions are met. This will certainly help such companies to make longer term investment decisions overseas.

    The Government could also help local companies venturing into new markets, such as Vietnam, Myanmar and Cambodia by setting up insurance schemes for country risks to help reduce their exposure to risks arising from war, terrorism, rebellion, insurrection, coup d'etat, etc. These events are usually not insurable commercially. If available, they are either limited in coverage or the premium would be too hefty. Such Government support, I am sure, would be most welcome by many Singapore companies and would certainly encourage them to venture more boldly into new markets.

Tax Changes for Individuals

    The across-the-board one-off rebate of 10% on individual income tax in the Year of Assessment 1997 is indeed a welcome relief for all of us, especially in a year of high property prices and escalating COE

Column: 545

prices. For many of us, it is probably not enough to pay for the increase in the COE prices since the beginning of the year.

    I commend the Government for finally consenting to raise the income tax relief for dependants by a modest amount of $500. My only regret is that the Government did not use the opportunity to increase the allowable relief for wife to at least the same level as for our aged parents at about $3,500 to $4,500. Those of you who have wives who are not working and also aged parents to support will know what I mean. Why should a non-working wife who is active economically managing your home be given a tax relief which is lower than that for your aged parents? Will the Minister help explain the rationale for this?

    Next, I also fail to understand why the top marginal tax bracket for individuals should be maintained at 28%, which is 2% higher than the corporate tax rate of 26%. Today, very high net worth individuals who are affected will have tax consultants and private bankers to help them to minimise their tax exposure. The end result may be more funds being kept abroad in tax havens to minimise their tax burdens. I have some suggestions too on property tax, estate duty and tax reliefs to promote regionalisation, which I will touch upon in greater detail in the Committee of Supply.

Rebates on HDB Service and Conservancy and Rental Charges.

    These rebates were introduced some years ago as a result of the GST offset package which made 70% of individuals non income tax payers. Although these rebates were initially meant to be one-off, the Government has been giving these rebates year after year now because of good budget surpluses. My concern is that we may soon have 70% of the population developing a welfare mentality as they come to expect this and other handouts such as Edusave, CPF top-up schemes and so on year after year. What I would like to see is for these rebates to be confined to the lower income only, ie, perhaps the

Column: 546

1-roomers, 2-roomers and 3-roomers who are tenants or lessees who are more in need of financial aid.

Budget Surplus.

    First of all, I think it is commendable that we have a budget surplus year after year. Many countries with much heavier tax rates are still grappling with breaking even on their budget. Recently, I read that we have broken the record of having the biggest budget surplus in the whole world, both as a percentage of GDP as well as in absolute quantum. This is a dubious honour that I think we should look in greater detail. It could mean that we are collecting revenue way above the Government's spending needs, thereby taking away cash and hence liquidity from the economic system. The retailers would like to believe in this theory as they attribute the poor purchasing power of consumers to lack of disposable income on households who are committed to large mortgage payments on houses and their cars. If this theory is correct and liquidity is tight, then you expect the interest rate to be high, which is not. In my view, the weak retail sector is due to more than just poor disposable income. Our consumers here and those from neighbouring countries have become much more discerning and are going for greater value-for-money purchases elsewhere in the region and even further afield as more and more people travel abroad.

Obviously they do, as a dollar more spent on a car would be a dollar less spent on other goods. What are the long term implications of having large budget surpluses on our local economy year after year? I am not an economist and I do not know the full answer right now, but I share the sentiments of many that it must be taking away some of the vibrance and enthusiasm of living in Singapore and contributing to the perception that Singapore is a very expensive place to live in.

Column: 547



    Last week, Singapore also won another dubious honour of being among the most expensive cities for expatriate housing.     Sir, with this comment, I support the motion in the name of the Finance Minister.
